alert.note: Alert for Lower Clark Fork Region (Montana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Missoula (Western Montana and Central Idaho)
info.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued February 18 at 2:25PM MST until February 22 at 5:00AM MST by NWS Missoula
info.description: ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM MST THIS EVENING ABOVE 3500 FEET... ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 5 PM SUNDAY TO 5 PM MST MONDAY ABOVE 3500 FEET... ...WINTER STORM WATCH IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH LATE TUESDAY NIGHT... * WHAT...For the first Winter Weather Advisory above 3500 feet, snow. Additional snow accumulations of 1 to 3 inches through this evening. For the second Winter Weather Advisory above 3500 feet, snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 5 to 14 inches, 1 to 2 inches possible for elevations below 3500 feet. For the Winter Storm Watch, heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 8 inches in the valleys and 18 to 24 inches for the mountains including Lookout Pass are possible. Blowing and drifting snow, dangerously cold wind chills and a freeze up on roadways is possible Tuesday evening with an arctic front passage. * WHERE...Evaro Hill, Highway 200 Thompson Falls to Plains, Highway 200 Trout Creek to Heron, and I-90 Lookout Pass to Haugan. * WHEN...For the first Winter Weather Advisory, until 7 PM MST this evening. For the second Winter Weather Advisory, from 5 PM Sunday to 5 PM MST Monday. For the Winter Storm Watch, from Monday afternoon through late Tuesday night. * IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Patchy blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The cold wind chills as low as 20 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.
info.instruction: Slow down and use caution while traveling. Monitor the latest forecasts for updates on this situation. The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can be obtained by calling 5 1 1.
